div.p: Greetings. What shall I write or say, my brother Fabricius? Sorrow follows sorrow and increases beyond measure. You know how much pain has been stirred in me by the deaths of my loved ones.
Now the death of the most illustrious, learned, and holy man, Mr. Gessner, almost kills me.
O wretched me, who, half-alive, am forced to follow so many funerals. But since it pleases the Lord so, I willingly submit myself to His discipline.
Last night he passed away at the 11th hour to the Lord; yesterday, bidding me farewell, he professed his faith and commended himself to the mercy of God through Christ.
He labored until his last breath; yesterday he even wrote some things. He never lay down, always either sat or walked about.
On Sunday he was still in the sacred assembly. A most pestilent anthrax seized his heart; a large boil settled under his left armpit. Grief does not allow me to say more.
All your letters and the money itself were delivered to me intact and correctly. What shall I say? I truly owe you much; therefore, I will not show myself ungrateful to you.
I give you my greatest thanks.
I will write to Mr. Councillor Tscharner when I have more spirit; meanwhile, you act on my behalf immediately.
I have many things about the uncovered treacheries from France, but I cannot write them.
Pray to the Lord for us.
He will be buried at 4 in the afternoon.
